    content => string (1154) "<blockquote> <p>#include <bits/stdc++.h></p> <p>using namespace std;</...
    $value[0]['content']
    <blockquote>
<p>#include <bits/stdc++.h></p>
<p>using namespace std;</p>
<p>double f(double x) {</p>
<p>// Example function, you can replace this with any function</p>
<p>return x*x; </p>
<p>}</p>
<p> </p>
<p>double trapezoidalRule(double a, double b, int n) {</p>
<p>    double h = (b - a) / n;</p>
<p>    double result = 0.5 * (f(a) + f(b));</p>
<p> </p>
<p>    for (int i = 1; i < n; i++) {</p>
<p>        result += f(a + i*h);</p>
<p>    }</p>
<p>    return h * result;</p>
<p>}</p>
<p> </p>
<p>int main() {</p>
<p>    double a = 0.0, b = 1.0; // Integration limits</p>
<p>    int n = 10; // Number of subintervals</p>
<p>    double ans  = trapezoidalRule(a, b, n);</p>
<p>    cout << "True value: " << 0.333333 << endl;</p>
<p>    cout << "Approximate value: " <</p>
<p>    cout << "Error Percentage: " << abs(0.333333-ans)*100 << "%" << endl; </p>
<p>    return 0;</p>
<p>}</p>
</blockquote>

    ⇄⧉
    content => string (3829) "<p>Data communication means exchanging information between two or more devic...
    $value[1]['content']
    <p>Data communication means exchanging information between two or more devices using some transmission medium.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Effectiveness of Data Communication Layer: (DATJ)</p>
<ol>
<li>Delivery, 2. Accuracy, 3. Timeliness, 4. Jitter</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p>Components of Data Communication</p>
<ol>
<li>Message, 2. Sender, 3. Receiver, 4. Transmission Medium, 5. Protocol</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p>Data Representation</p>
<ol>
<li>Text, 2. Number, 3. Images, 4. Audios, 5. Videos</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p>Data Flow</p>
<ol>
<li>Simplex, 2. Half Duplex, 3. Full Duplex</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p>Network Criteria (PRS)</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Performance →</p>
<p>a. Throughput</p>
<p>The throughput is a measure of how fast we can actually send data through a network</p>
<p>Unit: bps</p>
<p>b. Latency</p>
<p>The latency or delay defines how long it takes for an entire message to completely arrive at the destination from when the first bit is sent out from the source.</p>
<p>Latency = propagation time + transmission time + queuing time + processing delay</p>
<p>Unit: second</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reliability,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Security</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ul>
<p>What is a network? Interconnection between devices</p>
<p>Network components → 1. Host, 2. Connecting Devices ( Router, Switch, Modem)</p>
<p>Router → Network to Network Connection</p>
<p>Switch → Device to Device Connection</p>
<p>Modem → Data form exchange</p>
<p>Types of Connections → 1. Wired, 2. Wireless</p>
<p>Wired Connection → 1. Point to Point, 2. Multi-point</p>
<p>Topologies → 1. Bus, 2. Ring, 3. Mesh, 4. Star</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Accessing the Internet</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Using Telephone → Dial-up and DSL</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Using Wireless Network → point-to-point WAN</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Using Cable Network → Through Cable</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Direct Connect to the Internet → ISP</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Switches →</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Circuit Switched Network</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Packed Switched Network</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Two popular Data Communication Models:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>OSI → 1. Application, 2. Presentation, 3. Session, 4. Transport, 5. Network, 6. Data-link, 7. Physical</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>TCP/IP → 1. Application, 2. Transport, 3. Network, 4. Data-link, 5. Physical</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Two principles for all protocols:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>First principle: Each layer needs to work on two opposite tasks.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Second principle: Each layer must be identical between the source and destination</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Addressing each layer of TCP/IP:</p>
<div>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<td>Packet</td>
<td>Layers</td>
<td>Address</td>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Message</td>
<td>Application</td>
<td>Name</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Segment/ User Datagram</td>
<td>Transport</td>
<td>Port Number</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Datagram</td>
<td>Network</td>
<td>Logical Address</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Frame</td>
<td>Data-link</td>
<td>Data-link Address</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Bits</td>
<td>Physical</td>
<td>-</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
<p>Lacks of OSI Model Success:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>To replace the infrastructure from TCP/IP to OSI model, it needs a lot of time and money,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Services are not fully described in the presentation and session layer of the OSI model and</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Performances are insufficient to attract ISOC to switch TCP/IP to the OSI model.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>There are 4 signals:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Periodic Analog Signal,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-periodic Analog Signal,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Periodic Digital Signal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-periodic Digital Signal</p>
</li>
</ol>
